channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Fukushima Workers Who Fled May Have Received Garbled Orders, Reports Say
item.description: Some 650 workers who fled the Fukushima Daiichi plant without permission during the 2011 nuclear accident may have thought they had been ordered to evacuate, Japanese news media have reported.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: No More Dams on the Mekong
item.description: The environmental and socioeconomic costs of major hydropower projects on the river are too great.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID ROBERTS
item.media:description: The Mekong River in Luang Prabang, Laos.

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Franco-German Decoupling
item.description: The stalled eurozone would be much better off powered once again by a dual engine.
item.dc:creator: By SYLVIE KAUFFMANN

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: From Taiwan, Broad Support for Democracy in Hong Kong
item.description: Taiwan’s main political parties have backed Hong Kong residents’ calls for a greater say in choosing their leader, following Beijing’s decision this week to limit electoral reforms in the city.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Demonstrators took to the streets of Taiwan's capital, Taipei, in March to protest a cross-strait agreement with China on trade in services.

item.title: Ukrainian President’s Office Announces Cease-Fire With Russia
item.description: President Petro O. Poroshenko said Ukraine had reached a deal with Russia for the crisis in eastern Ukraine, but a Kremlin spokesman said Russia could not negotiate a cease-fire because it was not a party to the conflict.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:description: President Obama arriving at the Kadriorg Palace in Tallinn, Estonia, on Wednesday.

item.title: Video Showing Execution of Steven Sotloff Is Authentic, U.S. Says
item.description: The White House confirmed that the video released by the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria showing the beheading of Steven J. Sotloff, an American journalist, was authentic.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS

item.title: 2 South Korean Soldiers Die in Anti-Captivity Training
item.description: The soldiers apparently suffocated during an exercise meant to prepare them for being taken prisoner by the enemy, a military spokesman said Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Ren Jianming on the Fight Against Corruption in China, and His Own Solution
item.description: Ren Jianming, one of China’s leading experts on corruption, discusses the enormous scale of the problem and the challenge of keeping government functioning while pursuing it “to the end,” as President Xi Jinping has vowed.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Ren Jianming, professor at the Beihang University School of Public Policy and Management.

item.title: U.N. and Medical Group Make Appeals for Ebola Aid
item.description: United Nations officials urged diplomats to cable their capitals to send money, doctors and protective gear to the affected region, while Doctors Without Borders called for countries to send biohazard experts.
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: In Interviews, 3 Americans Held in North Korea Plead for U.S. Help
item.description: The three were interviewed by CNN and The Associated Press, and the choreography of the interviews suggested that North Korea wanted to use the prisoners as bargaining leverage.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Berlin Journal: Monument Seeks to End Silence on Killings of the Disabled by the Nazis
item.description: In Germany, some 300,000 people were added to the list of those to be remembered as victims of the Holocaust.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY
item.media:description: In a view through its centerpiece blue glass wall, a monument in Berlin to some 300,000 mentally ill and intellectually disabled people put to death by the Nazis.

item.title: Brazil’s Politicians Often Play the Clown in Ads
item.description: Before the Oct. 5 elections in Brazil, candidates are creating jaw-dropping campaign advertisements to grab hold of voters’ attention and to stand out.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO

item.title: ISIS Says It Killed Steven Sotloff After U.S. Strikes in Northern Iraq
item.description: The group released a video showing the beheading of a second American, blaming President Obama for the death and raising the pressure on him to order strikes on the group in Syria.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER and ERIC SCHMITT

item.title: U.S. and Europe Are Struggling With Response to a Bold Russia
item.description: Officials hope that any new measures will have more impact than the economic sanctions imposed on Moscow so far.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER and STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pieces of a Ukrainian tank littered a road after recent clashes in the strategic town of Ilovaysk, a transportation hub about 28 miles east of Donetsk, Ukraine.

item.title: Israel Says Hamas Is Hurt Significantly
item.description: In a recap of the 50-day war in Gaza, Israel says that it killed several hundred militants, and that militant groups operating in Gaza still have as many as 3,000 rockets on hand.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Yemeni President Dismisses Government After Weeks of Unrest
item.description: Yemen’s president proposed a national unity administration and suggested reinstating fuel subsidies, government officials said, in moves aimed at quelling weeks of unrest.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Palestinian Leaders Seek Actions in Security Council and Court
item.description: A senior aide to Mahmoud Abbas said he would seek a Security Council resolution to compel Israel to withdraw.
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA and RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: To Temper Unrest in Western China, Officials Offer Money for Intermarriage
item.description: The incentives are a trial policy in Xinjiang, an area where ethnic tensions between Uighurs and Han have erupted into violence recently.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: Uighurs wait at a bus stop in Xinjiang, China.

item.title: Airstrike in Somalia by U.S. Forces Targets Shabab Leader
item.description: Somali and American officials said Tuesday that the leader of the Shabab, the Somali militant group that has allied itself with Al Qaeda, may have been killed.
item.dc:creator: By JEFFREY GETTLEMAN and HELENE COOPER
item.media:description: A member of the Shabab, the Somali militant group, at a rally on the outskirts of Mogadishu in 2012.

item.title: World Briefing: India: Militants Are Killed in Shootout in Kashmir
item.description: The Indian authorities said they killed three antigovernment militants Tuesday after a shootout in the Indian-administered region of Kashmir.
item.dc:creator: By HARI KUMAR

item.title: World Briefing: Mali: U.N. Peacekeepers Die After Convoy Hits Mine
item.description: At least four United Nations peacekeepers were killed and 15 wounded when their convoy hit a mine in northern Mali on Tuesday, a spokesman said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Saudi Arabia: 88 Held on Suspicion of Terrorist Ties
item.description: Saudi Arabia has detained 88 people on suspicion of plotting terrorist attacks at home and abroad, the Interior Ministry said Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Charges Dropped Against British Parents of Ill Child
item.description: The British parents who took their critically ill child, Ashya, to Spain for treatment without doctors’ consent were released from a prison outside Madrid, their lawyer said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: U.S. Health Agency Advises Colleges to Tighten Ebola Precautions on Campuses
item.description: The new recommendations from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention came as thousands of foreign students and workers, and Americans who have been traveling abroad, began arriving on campuses to start a new school year.
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.dc:creator: By RICHARD PÉREZ-PEÑA

item.title: World Briefing: Syria: Militants Set Demands for Release of Fijians
item.description: Fiji’s military commander said Tuesday that Syrian rebels have issued three demands for the release of 45 Fijian peacekeepers who have been held captive since late last week.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
